newsitem.title: UK: LME options declaration calm despite early jitters.
newsitem.headline: LME options declaration calm despite early jitters.

text.p: The September London Metal Exchange (LME) options declaration passed smoothly on Wednesday despite an early scare when copper prices probed higher.
Options market makers were mostly short of calls at $2,100 a tonne, and when three months copper touched $2,070 on the pre-market September copper was valued at around $2,100.
Some futures buying emerged from the options market as a cover against the calls, but calm was quickly restored when the market drifted back.

"It was a bit touch-and-go when we got to $2,100 early on, and options related buying emerged just prior to that," said one options trader. "But in the end it was all very easy. Calm prevailed in the end," he added.
"The declaration was dead after the intial small run up," said another.
In the event September copper was indicated at around $2,075 at declaration, comfortably between the $2,050 and $2,100 strikes. Calls at $2,100 were abandoned and puts declared.
Open interest on $2,100 calls was large at 2,169 lots (equivalent to 54,225 tonnes) as at the close of trade Tuesday.

There was also sizeable open interest on $2,000 calls (1,475 lots, or 36,875 tonnes) and $2,200 calls (1,050 lots, or 26,250 tonnes). Put open interest at $2,000 and $2,100 was smaller, but at $2,200 it was a hefty 1,838 lots (45,950 tonnes). Market makers were generally short of calls at the $2,100 and $2,200 strikes, helping to push copper values sharply higher on Monday when September copper briefly rose above $2,200.
"Market makers were short of these calls and that is why we got such a violent move up and very soon after a move straight back down again," said a trader.
As well as covering on the futures market, dealers rushed to buy nearby options as an alternative source of cover, forcing volatilities sharply higher before they began to ease again.
September was said by some dealers to have traded as high as 75 percent volatility earlier this week.
The excercise was an expensive one for some players on the options market, many having lost large amounts of money during the plunge in prices in May and June.
"It's one step forward, two steps back for a lot of options players at the moment," said one dealer.
Soon after the declaration copper prices fell back sharply, losing $30 during the official ring.
But options traders said the move was not obviously related to the options market.
The only other areas of interest at declaration were in aluminium and lead.
September aluminium values were indicated at $1,475 at the time of declaration, and calls at that strike were partially declared while puts were abandoned, traders said.
Open interest was not large and underlying futures prices have been stable throughout the morning session.
Call option open interest at $1,475 on Tuesday was 440 lots (11,000 tonnes) and on puts 429 lots (10,725 tonnes).
Lead calls at $825 were also partially declared, although open interest on those options was small at 80 lots (2,000 tonnes).
All other base metals settled between strike prices and failed to feature at declaration, options traders said.
